thread.title_full: NAB completes 'once in a lifetime ' IT upgrade | Business Spectator

author: Supratim Adhikari
title: NAB completes 'once in a lifetime ' IT upgrade
text:
National Australia Bank has completed the final step in what it calls a “once in a lifetime” infrastructure upgrade, with the bank moving all of its technology backbone into its new data centre.
The data centre, situated in the west Melbourne suburb of Deer Park, was opened in 2013 and is now set to be the central nexus of the technology that underpins NAB’s customer offerings — from mobile banking to contactless payments.
With hundreds of billions of dollars of transactions flowing through the servers at Deer Park, NAB group executive, Enterprise Services and Transformation, Renée Roberts said that the upgrade reinforces the technology backbone of the bank at a time when demands are ramping up
“Technology is a key enabler and we needed to modernise how we did things,” Ms Roberts told The Australian.
“We needed to move to a more managed services model and something that was more agile.”
The data centre move has been four years in the making and has allowed NAB to rationalise the backend infrastructure to better manage loads on the server and alleviate capacity issues during times of peak demand.
“We now pay for only what we use,” Ms Roberts said.
Despite reaching this significant milestone, Ms Roberts added that NAB can’t afford to rest on its laurels and staying ahead of the technology curve requires constant innovation.
“This is a very complex environment and every year we will need to do new stuff and refining the underlying infrastructure,” she said.
“We have a list of things that are longer than we can keep track of sometime.”
The robustness of the back-end systems is crucial for banks to deliver on the customer-focused digital solutions that are becoming increasing important for day to day banking. With major outages a relatively regular occurrence in the market, Ms Roberts said that while the move to the new facility and the infrastructure-on-demand model adds significant reliability there’s no guarantee that outages will become a thing of the past.
The real challenge, according to Ms Roberts, is that while the myriad systems in the back-end tend to run well most of the time they often don’t react well to change
“When you leave these systems alone they tend to run fine but what tends to happen is when you change things sometimes they don’t like it,” she said.
NAB has instituted strict change procedures to mitigate the problem of a system shutdown but Ms Roberts said that outages can still happen.
“The technology is complex but customers must not feel the pain of the complexity,” she said.
“I don’t think we have nailed that just yet.”
